private_information: I operate on the left region of the table and observed the initial stacks and the full action log.
I am responsible for verifying the topmost block conditions before each move.
worker_alpha.goal: Observe the initial blocks configuration and the action sequence and produce a concise state transition report.

private_information: I operate on the right region of the table and observed the initial stacks and the full action log.
I am responsible for verifying pick and put operations and reporting any temporary table placements.
worker_beta.goal: Observe the initial blocks configuration and the action sequence and produce a concise state transition report.

private_information: I receive reports from the workers and must produce a final PDDL domain and problem for FastDownwards.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate worker reports and produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that encodes the final arrangement of blocks.

public_information: This is a standard Blocks World domain. Only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
The set of blocks is A B C D E F G H I J K L M.

Initial arrangement: A is on top of K. B is on top of C. C is on the table. D is on top of E. E is on top of I. F is on top of M. G is on the table. H is on top of F. I is on top of G. J is on top of H. K is on top of B. L is on top of A. M is on top of D.

Action log executed in order: 1 unstack(J,H). 2 putdown(J). 3 pickup(J). 4 putdown(J). 5 pickup(J). 6 stack(J,H). 7 unstack(J,H). 8 stack(J,L). 9 unstack(J,L). 10 stack(J,H). 11 unstack(J,H). 12 stack(J,H). 13 unstack(J,H). 14 putdown(J). 15 pickup(J). 16 putdown(J). 17 pickup(J). 18 stack(J,L). 19 unstack(J,L). 20 stack(J,L). 21 unstack(H,F). 22 stack(H,J). 23 unstack(F,M). 24 stack(F,H). 25 unstack(F,H). 26 stack(F,H). 27 unstack(M,D). 28 stack(M,D). 29 unstack(M,D). 30 stack(M,D). 31 unstack(M,D). 32 stack(M,D). 33 unstack(M,D). 34 stack(M,F). 35 unstack(D,E). 36 stack(D,M). 37 unstack(D,M). 38 stack(D,M). 39 unstack(D,M). 40 putdown(D). 41 unstack(E,I). 42 putdown(E). 43 unstack(I,G). 44 putdown(I). 45 pickup(E). 46 stack(E,D). 47 unstack(E,D). 48 stack(E,M). 49 pickup(G). 50 putdown(G).
Task: Using the initial configuration and the actions, derive the final arrangement of each block and whether it is on the table or on top of another block.

observe.system_prompt: You are worker_alpha. Examine the environment public information, especially the initial arrangement and the action log. Produce a concise, ordered state transition report that lists moves and the immediate effect on stacks. Do not emit PDDL. Output should be a single-line structured report indicating for each step which block was picked or placed and the resulting top elements of affected stacks.
observe.prompt: Your name is worker_alpha. You have the following private information: {agents->worker_alpha->private_information}. You see the environment public information: {environment->public_information}. Produce a concise state transition report that will serve as an input for orchestration. Keep the report factual and avoid assumptions beyond the given log.

observe.system_prompt: You are worker_beta. Examine the environment public information, especially the initial arrangement and the action log. Produce a concise, ordered state transition report emphasizing pick and putdown operations and any temporary table placements. Do not emit PDDL. Output should be a single-line structured report indicating for each step which block was moved and where it ended up after the move.
observe.prompt: Your name is worker_beta. You have the following private information: {agents->worker_beta->private_information}. You see the environment public information: {environment->public_information}. Produce a concise state transition report that will serve as an input for orchestration. Keep the report factual and avoid assumptions beyond the given log.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the workers reports and the public information to produce a single complete PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep actions of different agents logically distinct if needed. Target FastDownwards conventions and ensure the problem encodes the final arrangement of blocks as the goal state.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You receive worker reports and the environment public information. Your goal is to produce a PDDL domain and problem for FastDownwards that encodes the final arrangement of blocks after the recorded action sequence. Integrate the following reports and the public information and resolve any minor naming discrepancies. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
